title: Applied Navigation: Reduced Visibility. Uncertain of Position/Lost Procedures.

questions.question: If forced to navigate in reduced visibility, make all effort to maintain ____________________, and resist temptation to ____________________.
questions.answer: Visual contact with the surface. Climb through clouds.

questions.question: Give three reasons why you should avoid climbing through holes in clouds in reduced visibility.
questions.answer: Light aircraft performance decreases significantly with an increase in altitude. Manoeuvering between clouds may require steep angles of bank, further reducing aircraft performance. Severe risk of disorientation.

questions.question: What is a good rule of thumb for flying among or above cloud cover?
questions.answer: Avoid flying among or above clouds that cover more than half the sky (4 oktas).

questions.question: How does flying in low visibility affect checkpoints?
questions.answer: They may be harder to see, possibly not until you're over them.

questions.question: What should you keep in mind when selecting checkpoints if you have to fly in low visibility conditions?
questions.answer: Select as many as practical. Select on-track checkpoints when possible (you may not be able to see off-track ones).

questions.question: What should you consider about timing when flying in bad weather?
questions.answer: If flying in the bad weather configuration, EETs need to be updated to reflect the new groundspeed.

questions.question: When passing checkpoints, especially in low visibility, you should ____________________.
questions.answer: Mark them clearly on your map, and note the time you passed them.

questions.question: What is a major consideration if you depart from your flight planned track in bad weather?
questions.answer: Terrain or obstacles along the unplanned route.

questions.question: If forced down due to bad weather, what is a consideration about other aircraft? What can you do to respond to this?
questions.answer: They may be in the same situation. Keep a good lookout. Turn on all external lights. Broadcast position and intentions as required.

questions.question: What does 'Uncertain of Position' mean? What should you do in this situation?
questions.answer: Expected checkpoints don't appear, doubt exists about your precise position. Continue flight and be alert for the next checkpoint.

questions.question: What does 'Lost' mean?
questions.answer: Unable to relate features on the chart to ground features. Continuing flight doesn't result in definite orientation.

questions.question: Complete these Uncertain of Position procedures: 1. Enter __________ and __________ on your flight log or chart. 2. Check the ____________________ to determine if this is the cause of the discrepancy. 3. If (2) was the cause, apply the error to the required track from your ____________________ to give you an approximate current position. 4. Synchronise the __________ then make a heading change in order to intercept the __________.
questions.answer: Time and current heading. DI against compass. Last known position. The DI. Required/flight planned track.

questions.question: Complete these Uncertain of Position procedures: 1. Enter __________ and __________ on your flight log or chart. 2. Check the ____________________ to determine if this is the cause of the discrepancy. 3. If (2) is not the cause, consider whether the cause was flying an ____________________. If so, note this and make a similar change in the __________ direction. 4. If your next checkpoint doesn't appear, start __________ procedures.
questions.answer: Time and current heading. DI against compass. Incorrect heading. Opposite. Lost.

questions.question: If you're lost, what are four methods that may help you find your location? Give a brief description of each.
questions.answer: Altitude: the higher you are the further you can see (cloud or controlled airspace may prevent this). Reverse track: make a 180° turn and fly back the way you came until you establish your position again. Geography: given the relatively narrow width of NZ (with the exception of the centraly North Island), flying East or West should lead you to a coast. ATC: most of NZ is under radar coverage, consider asking ATC for help. You may need to climb to receive radar or communication coverage.

questions.question: Complete these lost procedures: 3. Note the __________. 2. __________ to give time to do calculations. 3. Check the flight log or chart for __________ flown since the last definite fix, draw estimated __________. 4. Determine the MPP (__________), within the MPA (__________), estimate the __________ from the last positive fix to help narrow down this area. 5. Once this area is established, look at the ground to see if you ____________________.
questions.answer: Time. Orbit. Heading. TMG (Track Made Good). Most Probable Postion. Most Probable Area. Groundspeed. Recognise any features.

questions.question: Once you've marked the MPP, what are three recommended methods for establishing the MPA?
questions.answer: 1. Estimate two lines at 30° either side of the estimated track. 2.) Draw two points either side of the MPP, one 10nm before, and one 10nm after. 3. Draw a circle around the MPP with a radius of 10% of the estimated distance.

questions.question: When in a lost situation, read from the (ground/chart) to the (ground/chart).
questions.answer: Ground. Chart.

questions.question: What ground features can help with orientation?
questions.answer: Roads, railways, lakes, rivers.

questions.question: How can valleys be used to establish position when lost?
questions.answer: If in or near a valley, determine the orientation and compare to orientation of valleys on the chart. Eliminate any that don't match the orientiation of the actual valley.

questions.question: While executing Lost procedures, if you positively identify a fix you should ____________________ and then ____________________.
questions.answer: Confirm with other nearby features. Use this to continue to your destination.

questions.question: While executing Lost procedures, what should you do if unable to identify your location after establishing a MPP and MPA? If still unable, what is your next decision?
questions.answer: Increase the size of the MPA. Executing a precautionary landing, or depart the MPA.

questions.question: What are four factors which help determine whether you should remain in the MPA and execute a __________, or depart the MPA?
questions.answer: Fuel remaining. Surrounding terrain. Daylight remaining. Weather.

questions.question: If you decide to depart the MPA, you should leave via a __________. Give examples, and reasons why these can be particularly useful.
questions.answer: Well defined feature. Roads, railways. Roads and railways often lead to towns or other major feature that can be identified.

questions.question: If you believe you can continue via an alternate route, you should select speed for maximum (range/endurance). If you need time to figure out the situation, select speed for maximum (range/endurance).
questions.answer: Range. Endurance.

questions.question: What are two engine settings you should consider when executing Lost procedures?
questions.answer: Ensure the mixture is fully rich if flying at low level (or properly set otherwise). Be wary of carb icing if flying in bad weather.

questions.question: When executing Lost or Unsure of Position procedures, what is important with regard to note taking?
questions.answer: Record the steps you've taken.
